description: From Old French arrumage (compare French arrimage), from arrumer (“to arrange the cargo in the hold”) (compare French arrimer and Spanish arrumar).

entries.meaning: A thorough search, usually resulting in disorder.
examples: Have a rummage through the attic and see if you can find anything worth selling.

entries.meaning: A disorganized collection of miscellaneous objects; a jumble.
(nautical) A place or room for the stowage of cargo in a ship.
(nautical) The act of stowing cargo; the pulling and moving about of packages incident to close stowage.

verbs.description: rummage (third-person singular simple present rummages, present participle rummaging, simple past and past participle rummaged)

entries.meaning: (transitive, nautical) To arrange (cargo, goods, etc.) in the hold of a ship; to move or rearrange such goods.
(transitive, nautical) To search a vessel for smuggled goods.
examples: After the long voyage, the customs officers rummaged the ship.

definitionGroups.group: (transitive) To search something thoroughly and with disregard for the way in which things were arranged.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To hastily search for something in a confined space and among many items by carelessly turning things over or pushing things aside.
examples: She rummaged in the drawers trying to find the missing sock.
